qas.question: In order for a unconstitutional statue to disappear, it has to be deleted by?
What has remained on the books after they were ruled unconstitutional?
What principle  states no lower court will enforce an unconstitutional statue?
Who can reverse an unconstitutional court ruling?
What must happen to a statute for it to become unconstitutional?
What can delete a statute and make it unconstitutional?
Some federal and state statutes remain on the books for how long after they are ruled unconstitutional?
What decisis states that no lower court will enforce an unconstitutional statute?
Any court that enforces an unconstitutional statute will be overturned by what court?
If a statute is unconstitutional, how is it removed?
What happens when an unconstitutional statute remains on the books?

answers.text: no sensible lower court will enforce

qas.question: What would happen if a lower court tried to enforce an unconstitutional statute?
What would happen if a lower court refused to uphold a constitutional law?

answers.text: risk reversal by the Supreme Court

qas.question: What must happen before the Supreme Court will reverse a decision by a lower court refusing to uphold a constitutional law?

answers.text: constitutionality has been expressly established in prior cases

qas.question: A statute is automatically removed when it is found to be what?
How long does it take for the principle of stare decisis to come into affect?
What is the name of the principle that demands that unconstitutional laws must be removed via subsequent rulings?
What kind of court can reverse unconstitutional enforcements by the Supreme Court?
What court created the principle of stare decisis?

context: Notably, a statute does not disappear automatically merely because it has been found <b14_0>unconstitutional<b14_0/>; <a4_0>it must be <a9_0>deleted<a4_0/> by <a0_0><a5_0>a subsequent statute<a9_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>. Many <a1_0>federal and state statutes<a1_0/> have remained on the books for <a6_0><b15_0>decades<b15_0/><a6_0/> after they were ruled to be unconstitutional. However, under <a7_0>the principle of <a2_0><b16_0>stare decisis<b16_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/>, <a10_0>no sensible <b17_0>lower<b17_0/> court will enforce<a10_0/> an unconstitutional statute, and any court that does so will be <a11_0>reversed by <a3_0><a8_0>the <b18_0>Supreme Court<b18_0/><a11_0/><a8_0/><a3_0/>. Conversely, any court that refuses to enforce a constitutional statute (where such <a13_0>constitutionality has been expressly established in prior cases<a13_0/>) will <a12_0>risk reversal by the Supreme Court<a12_0/>.
